title: 113_s643
content: The Act titled "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" aims to enhance cost savings. The Act "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" is amended to include provisions for the identification of surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority by the Inspector General of an agency or other agency employee. The Act "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" is amended to include provisions for the Inspector General or other agency employee to refer potential surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority to the Chief Financial Officer of the agency for review. The Act "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" allows the Inspector General or agency employee to identify surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority, which can be transferred to the Treasury's general fund by the agency head if it does not hinder effectiveness. Transfers are not subject to Title X of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" allows surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority to be transferred to the Treasury's general fund for deficit reduction or debt reduction. Agency heads can retain up to 10% of the transferred amounts for cash awards. The head of an agency can retain up to 10% of surplus funds transferred to the Treasury for cash awards to employees who identified the funds. Each agency must report any fraud, waste, or surplus funds identified by employees to the Office of Personnel Management annually. The head of each agency must report any fraud, waste, or surplus funds identified by employees annually. This report should include the total savings achieved, the number and amount of cash awards given, and be included in each budget request submitted to the Office of Management and Budget. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management must report on Federal cost savings and awards annually to Congress and the Government Accountability Office. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management must ensure agency cash award programs comply with the Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013 and report annually to Congress. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report to Congress every 3 years on Federal cost savings and awards. The Comptroller General of the United States must report to Congress every 3 years on the operation of the cost savings and awards program, with any recommendations for legislative changes. Officers eligible for cash awards are subject to certain prohibitions under Section 4509 of title 5, United States Code. Section 4509 of title 5, United States Code prohibits cash awards to certain officers, including those at level I of the Executive Schedule, agency heads, and members of independent establishments. The amendment to section 4509 of title 5, United States Code, prohibits cash awards to agency heads and members of independent establishments. Prohibition of cash awards to agency heads and members of independent establishments under section 4509 of title 5, United States Code.
